Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Compact Torus-Shaped Organic Ranking Cycle for Distributed Solar Thermal Power Generation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is in Organic Rankine Cycles for distributed solar power generation at micro scale and will offer a cheaper alternative to solar photovoltaic (PV), with a payback period of just 4.5 year without government incentives. The use of solar thermal to generate power at residential level would offer a renewed encouragement to the solar thermal industry. With the ability to provide heat and hot water plus electricity, the solar thermal powered product would fulfill the energy requirements of a home single handedly. Most are familiar with the traditional perspective on the societal impact of a system like the Compact ORC - lower energy demand and reduced greenhouse gas. In addition the CORC positively impacts health and wellbeing by improving indoor air quality and providing affordable access. A number of clinical studies connect improved indoor air quality from efficient systems with a reduction in respiratory and cardiovascular conditions. Combining the health benefits of clean indoor air and improved living conditions, the downstream impact on healthcare cost would be enormous.

This project attempts to solve the problem of high cost for renewable energy from solar energy, both PV and solar thermal, at the residential and light commercial level without government incentives. Solar thermal can provide heat and hot water but not electricity. PV can provide electricity but not heat and hot water. The Compact ORC concept can do both with Combined Heat and Power (CHP). Current ORC systems are bulky and inefficient and most importantly high cost. The objective of this research is to combine all of the components of the ORC in one compact, integrated, low cost package. The expander, pump, and generator will all be mounting on a common shaft. The evaporator and condenser heat exchangers will be mounted integral with the ORC reducing inefficiencies and packaging cost. There will be no external piping of components together. The result will be a compact unit that is cost and performance competitive with grid energy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To facilitate distributed solar thermal power generation, Air Squared proposed to design and develop a prototype power generation system based on an Organic Rankine Cycle (ORC) for light residential and commercial application. Key features of this proposed system were compact design, micro scale power capacity, efficient operation with low temperature heat source and cost effectiveness. After preliminary analysis and proving technical feasibility during phase I of the project, major objectives of the phase II were: 1) to design, develop and test major system components, and 2) to integrate and test a working prototype system. Phase II project goals were divided into a number of tasks distributed over the two years of project duration.

 

As per the proposal and work plan, using detailed analytical model analysis was conducted to select optimum operating conditions for the system. Ambient air at 25 C as the heat sink, hot water at 99 C as the heat source and expander rotational speed of 3600 RPM were selected as design point conditions to produce net-work of approximately 2.5 KW. It was predicted that overall system efficiency of 7.5 % will be achieved depending upon the component efficiencies assumed. R134a and R245fa were selected as two potential optimum working fluids for high and low-pressure operation respectively.

 

Using the specified operating conditions all the major components of the prototype Compact Organic Rankine Cycle (CORC) system were sized. While, scroll expander and evaporator heat exchanger were designed and fabricated in house, the scroll pump and generator were outsourced. All the components were performance tested on the ORC test setup designed and fabricated at Air Squared. Components were modified as required to achieve the desired performance. Overall expander efficiency of 62% and heat exchanger efficiency of 75% were achieved.  Finally, the integrated CORC system was designed and assembled at Air Squared. CORC performance testing conducted at Air Squared, not only proved the concept but also successfully demonstrated working of all the components together as a system. However, limited funding stalled the development process which now requires another design iteration to address the internal volumetric and mechanical losses, required for the commercialization of the technology.  

 

Costing analysis conducted for production quantities of 1000, 5000 and 10000 estimated the CORC system cost of approximately $4000, $3300 and $2800 respectively (excluding the cost of any heat source). This provides an extremely attractive payback period of around a year for applications where heat source hardware in not required, for example, waste heat recovery applications.  Talks are underway with potential industry partners for follow on funding and further development of the system.


Last Modified: 01/11/2018
Modified by: Bryce R Shaffer

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: To facilitate distributed solar thermal power generation, Air Squared proposed to design and develop a prototype power generation system based on an Organic Rankine Cycle (ORC) for light residential and commercial application. Key features of this proposed system were compact design, micro scale power capacity, efficient operation with low temperature heat source and cost effectiveness. After preliminary analysis and proving technical feasibility during phase I of the project, major objectives of the phase II were: 1) to design, develop and test major system components, and 2) to integrate and test a working prototype system. Phase II project goals were divided into a number of tasks distributed over the two years of project duration. As per the proposal and work plan, using detailed analytical model analysis was conducted to select optimum operating conditions for the system. Ambient air at 25 C as the heat sink, hot water at 99 C as the heat source and expander rotational speed of 3600 RPM were selected as design point conditions to produce net-work of approximately 2.5 KW. It was predicted that overall system efficiency of 7.5 % will be achieved depending upon the component efficiencies assumed. R134a and R245fa were selected as two potential optimum working fluids for high and low-pressure operation respectively. Using the specified operating conditions all the major components of the prototype Compact Organic Rankine Cycle (CORC) system were sized. While, scroll expander and evaporator heat exchanger were designed and fabricated in house, the scroll pump and generator were outsourced. All the components were performance tested on the ORC test setup designed and fabricated at Air Squared. Components were modified as required to achieve the desired performance. Overall expander efficiency of 62% and heat exchanger efficiency of 75% were achieved. Finally, the integrated CORC system was designed and assembled at Air Squared. CORC performance testing conducted at Air Squared, not only proved the concept but also successfully demonstrated working of all the components together as a system. However, limited funding stalled the development process which now requires another design iteration to address the internal volumetric and mechanical losses, required for the commercialization of the technology. Costing analysis conducted for production quantities of 1000, 5000 and 10000 estimated the CORC system cost of approximately $4000, $3300 and $2800 respectively (excluding the cost of any heat source). This provides an extremely attractive payback period of around a year for applications where heat source hardware in not required, for example, waste heat recovery applications. Talks are underway with potential industry partners for follow on funding and further development of the system. Last Modified: 01/11/2018 Submitted by: Bryce R Shaffer
